text: - Hello and welcome to Community Chats.
I'm Aley Hammer,
and today we're interviewing Paul Erskine,

the Head of Digital and
Data Delivery at Strandbags.
Paul welcome to the show.

Over the last two years, the
world has definitely changed,
so can you share with us

how your customer's
expectations have changed
and how you guys at Strandbags

are actually supporting
these new expectations?
- For sure. Thank you Aley.
So yeah, over the last two years,

I think one of the big
changes is the expectation

around levels of service
across all channels
from in-store, online,

all the way through until
the order is delivered.

The customer really wants
a personalized experience,

they want to know how they've
engaged with the brand.

Um, and yeah the basically
the way we've tried
to accommodate that is we've built in some
personalization into our new website.

So that is something that
we're really focused on.
And we're also working on the build
of a new data platform

to really understand our
customers in the best way.

- Well I must say I
personally love Strandbags

and can attest to the fact
that your website is so great

and provides a very seamless
experience to your customers.

So with all the changes
to the digital experience,

what has the impact
been to both your online
and in-store presence?
- So yeah through the changes,
since we've deployed the new website,
the customers have responded really well.
So in parallel to that,
we've launched a new in-store experience.

And that, that in-store
experiences has really
elevated the brand.
So as we built the new website,

we wanted to, we wanted
to respond to that,

and we wanted the website
to really be a show case
in the same way the new stores are.
And that's the way it truly worked out.
We've also focused on,
focused on personalization as I mentioned,

we've put in a product
called High Conversion,

and in the backend that's
powered by AWS Personalize.
And since we've gone live,
we've seen around 19% of our online sales
have been driven through the

product recommendation
sections of the new website

so that, as expected that
has been really successful.
- Well as a shopaholic myself,

you know, whenever you
get the recommendations,

it's so helpful and I'm
often finding myself,
you know, being up-sold.

So it's so great that you're
factoring all this in.
And what I want to know is

what role does AWS technology
actually play in all this?

And what impact does it
have on your business?
- We have a, an AWS middleware

that was built as part
of our new, web builds.
We have our core systems that sit in-house
and we have a new website on Shopify,
but in between those two systems,
we have an AWS middleware
and that's where we will look at
what stock do we have in each store?

What are the, what's the
closest store to the customer?
So a lot of our sales result
in click and collect orders being placed.

So we want to work out, okay
which stores have the stock?
What's the closest store to the customer?

So that we can provide
them with the best options.
We're also looking at how do we
provide enhanced delivery options?
So how do we reduce the time it takes us
to get the product to the customer.
So that's a big focus for 2022,

looking at building on
that middleware platform

and looking at how do
we provide the customer
with enhanced options.
We're also in the process of building out
a new data platform.
So look building a data lake,
building a data warehouse, all on AWS,
so from the data warehouse
where we're looking at using a Redshift.

We've been monitoring the
developments of Redshift
over the last couple of years,

we're really impressed with
where that's at the moment.
Once we have the data in the data lake

we'll be looking to
bring in AWS SageMaker,

and we use that to really derive
machine learning insights,

to power different use
cases across the business.

And we're also doing a proof
of concept of AWS QuickSight,

we're looking at choosing
the best a BI tool
to build our reporting platform on,

and AWS QuickSight is
part of that evaluation.

So again really looking at
tapping into the power of AWS
to get things up and running quickly
through using that proven technology
where we're confident we'll see some,
some really good results.
- Well the data lake you're building
will provide so many insights,
and I cannot wait to watch your journey
and continue working with you guys.
So on this actually,

what does the future
look like for Strandbags?

- We're looking to really
become a data powered business.

So by building out the data
lake, the data warehouse,
the key objective of that initiative
is to give each department
so from merchandise, retail, supply chain,
our property team, finance team.

We want to give each team
in the Strandbag's business,

the ability to track
performance against targets,
but also to derive some key insights

so one of the key things
we'll be looking at
is where is our inventory?
What do we have in the DC?
What's being delivered?
What's in store?
what's on the shelf?

And really use data to drive
each part of the business.
So we're excited about
progressing this journey quickly
and through using AWS,

we're really confident we
can get some good results

and really build on that
partnership over time.

- Paul it's been so cool
to watch your journey,
particularly over the last two years,
when I think consumers like myself,
you know, who are stuck in lockdown,
are definitely becoming more demanding

and their expectations
have absolutely changed.

It's really cool that you're
looking at all these options
with delivery and recommendation engine.

So thank you so much
for coming on the show
and talking about your journey.

And if anyone has any
questions for Strandbags,

please pop them in the
comment section below,
and we'll get back to you.
Thank you so much.
- Thank you.
